TWO NEW COURSES ANNOUNCED
One Leading to B. S. in Chemistry
Other, Leading to Admission to New
School of Hygiene'—Will Attract New Students.

The Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University have
announced two important new
courses, which have been established on account of the new school of
Hygiene and Public Health and on
account of the demand for industrial chemistry. One course given
in the College of Arts and Sciences, leads to admission to the
new School of Hygiene. The other
course leads to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Chemistry.
Owing to conditions growing
out of the war and in response to
a demand from the agricultural
industries of the country, it was
felt that additional opportunities
should be offered to the young
men of the State to obtain training in advance chemical work
during the college course. The
new course is under the direction of the School of Engineering
and identical with the prescribed
engineering course for the first
two years. In the third year chemistry is substituted for two of the
engineering subjects, and in the
last year, practically all of the
student's..time is devoted to special work in the chemical laboratory. It is hoped that students in
this course will be better prepared
to carry on advanced work in all
lines of industrial chemistry than
students who have followed the
so-called courses in chemical-engineering, given by a number of
institutions throughout the country. Students who enter the new
course will be eligible to the State
scholarships awarded in, the Engineering School.
A student, who completes the
course, with two units of Latin
(which may be offered for matriculation) and with the equivalent
of Biology I (as certified by our
department of biology).will be accepted for admission to the Medical School.
An outline of the courses follows:
I.

IN MEMORY OF DR. MALL
(Remarks of President Goodnow,who
presided at the commemoration exercises for Dr. Mall on Sunday, February
3, at C. E. Hall.)

We are assembled here today to
honor the memory of our lamented colleague and friend Dr. Mall. Dr. Mall had been up to the
time of his death continuously and
uninterruptedly associated with
the Medical School from the time
of its opening. He was one of the
group who a quarter of a century
ago inaugurated a new venture in
medical instruction in this country. The purposes which were
then outlined, the ideas which
were then entertained, the methods which were then adopted had
subsequently a widespread influence throughout the land. It is
somewhat -difficult for us, separated as we are by so long a period from the original time of
their formulation and accustomed
as we are to the changes which
they caused, to appreciate how
novel and how important was the
work then undertaken.
For the success attendant upon
the Medical School Dr. Mall was
in no small measure responsible.
A brilliant and tireless investigator he made invaluable contributions to the science to which he
devoted himself and won prestige
for the institution with which he
was connected. A wise and sane
counselor he exercised a potent
and salutary influence over the
policy of the medical faculty. A
kindly and courteous gentleman
he greatly endeared himself to his
colleagues and associates.
Passing away in the prime of
life and at the height of his powers he leaves in the world of science a gap which it will be difficult to fill and among his friends
a sense of loss which it is impossible to overcome.
We have, however the satisfaction of knowing that
' the University of which he was a member
is better and finer for what he was
and did. His life and work will
long continue to be an inspiration to the colleagues he has left
behind and to the students whom
he taught.

Alex. Barton Writes From France.
[Alexander K. Barton, from whom
the following letter comes, was a prominent member of the Class of 1914. He
was elected Rhode Scholar in the year
he graduated, but had to forego the
privileges of the honor on account of
the war. He was also editor of THE
NEWS-LETTER during the year 19131914. THE NEWS-LEAThR is indebted
to Dean Brush for the privilege of
publishing this intensely interesting
account]

January 25, 1918.
149th F. A., A. E. F., France
DEAR MR. BRUSH—
I have been intending to write
for some time, but have been putting it off. Would that I had not
been so delinquent and had pursued Fraser and Squair more ardently! A lot of charming French
ladies hold a Red Cross (French)
Bazar at camp and how I curse
my inability to "parler" with fluency. We entertain them at our
officers mess, and after having
skillfully maneuvered so that
Mlle. la plus belle et plus charmante sits at my table, a sous-lieutenant comes along and does
nearly all the talking. Tell any of
your students to put the classics
aside, not to say the sciences, and
to learn French. I have met some
charming people. They are most
hospitable. Had a good game of
tennis the Sunday before Christmas with some French girls at a
town in Brittany. It was funny
to sap "pret?" and "guaranteeing." Being with Americans so
much and having no chance to
study, it is hard to make much
progress, but what French I did
know has come back in a remarkable way, and I have picked up a
lot. It has been a tremendous
pleasure to be able to talk to
French officers and to the country
people. When I cannot understand the spoken word I get them
to write it down. I had quite
an extensive conversation with a
French lieutenant en route from
Paris to this place (the First
Corps School). I have written
quite a few French letters. My
knowledge of French has been a
great help in a military way—so
many directions in regard to the
soixante-quinze and to signalling
apparatus are not yet translated.
I have seen quite a few interesting places—one old town near the
last camp. The castle walls are
still intact, a deep moat in front
of them and in the town a church
with beautiful stone carvings and
stained glass windows, built by
the English when they held that

part of France. I had two great
days in Paris. I translated what
our French guide had to say in
the Palais de Justice to a party
of officers. It is remarkable how
practice helps your French. I
saw Leslie Buckler in Paris. He
took me to supper at a club for allied officers, which occupies the
handsome house of Baron Rothschild.
I should think THE NEWS-LETTER or ALUMNI MAGAZINE Would
be interested in hearing of the
Johns Hopkins University men in
our first four thousand. There are
quite a few in the First Division.
Lieut.-Col. John Crane (who came
to see me one night, but whom I
missed). Maj. Redmond Stewart,
Acting Judge Advocate of the First
Division,Whom I see frequently, as
he is located here. Gillie, whom I
just ran into tonight here at the Y.
M. C. A., and Jim Manning. Hunting, a Phi Gama about '07, is here.
Jack Branham is at the Infantry
School here,I just learned tonight,
and shall look him up tomorrow.
Besides the Hopkins Unit (which
is nearby), there will be many of
us in the First Corps.
I am mighty anxious to get "aux
tranchees," and I guess I'll be as
ready to get out. The artillery
takes a long time to train unfortunately. We get splendid food—
can get excellently cooked meals
at the inns for four or five francs
if we want a change, but the army
food is really excellent. Our quarters are good, with plenty of wood,
but the last two weeks have been
so mild we often go without coats.
The Y. M. C. A. is closing and I
must stop. Hoping the Maryland
F. A. battalion will soon get over,
Fraternally,
ALEXANDER K. BARTON.
News From Capt. Elliott

A Training Camp, Somewhere in
France.
January 28, 1917.

MY DEAR DR. BRUSH:
Just a line to let you and my
many friends at Hopkins know
that I arrived safely across the
"big ditch" after an uneventful
voyage. We are hard at work here
under French instructors trying
to master the gentle art of
"beating the Dutch." The Army
seems to be in high spirits and
hopeful of an early whack at
Fritz so that we can all be home
for Christmas. Weather here like
spring at home, warm and sunny.
Our only woe is the hick of mail
and news. With kindest regards
to all at the club.
Please remember me to Konze,
Bitter, and "George," the Janitor.
C. W. ELLIOTT.
Warden—In this institution,
we aim to put every man to work
at his regular occupation.
Now what is your business?
No. 3333—Traveling salesman.
—Chaparal.

Savings Stamps.
These War-Savings Certificate

and

GOLD, because they are earning

edrning nothing.
Moreover.
The money you pay for a WarSavings Certificate Stamp is hell)

while
The gold you hold is not helping

Objects of Loan in this Form
The objects of the United States
Government in selling these WarSavings Certificate Stamps($5.00)
and Thrift Stamps (25 cents) are
fourfold:
1. To obtain $2,000,000,000 for
use in the prosecution of the
World War in which we are now
engaged;
2. To encourage habits of
economy and conservation upon
the part of our people, thereby
adding to the available wealth and
resources of our country, and
saving both for the use of our
military forces and those at home
who are in need;
3. To encourage the habits of
thrift and saving in America, and
4. To give every citizen of
America an opportunity to do his
or her part toward winning this
War for Universal Liberty.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 18, 1918.

BENSON TO LEAD BALL TEAM

LEARNS MORE ABOUT SHOOTING

LACROSSE SQUAD LOOKS GOOD

CLASS IN FENCING PROGRESSING

Star Outfielder of Last Year's Base
Ball Team Elected Captain at
Organization Meeting
For This Year.

Battalion Takes Up Work in Fire
Direction and Control— Results
of Examinations are
Unsatisfactory.

Men Are Getting Down to Real Work.
Schmidt,Sadtler,Morley and Winslow
Setting Fast Pace—New Men
Learn Quickly.

Sergt. Kistler's Proteges Are Rapidly
Learning the Art----Plan to Organize
a Fencing Team for Next Year.

If the enthusiasm of the large
crowd that attended the baseball
organization meeting held• on
Tuesday, February 12, in the Civil
Engineering Building, can be
taken as a criterion, the baseball
team this year, despite the loss of
so many men on account of the
war, will be one of the best that
has ever represented the Johns
Hopkins University. The chief
business of the meeting was the
election of a captain to lead the
1918 team, and "Dick" Benson,
last year's star outfielder, was selected for this honored position.
The baseball team lost the services of its captain for this year,
Stuart Egerton, when he enlisted
in the battery last spring. He is
now at Camp McClellan, Anniston, Alabama, with a whole colony of Hopkins men.
Coach Eddie Hooper was unable to get here to address the
men and Manager Coulter, who
was in charge of the meeting,
started things moving with the
election of a captain. There were
only two logical men for this position, Dick Benson and Lawrence
Littman, last year's third basemen, and Dick was elected. Benson, while only a sophomore, has
had considerable baseball experience, and is unquestionably qualified to perform the duties of captain. He played in the outfield in
all of the games last year and was
the individual star in many of
them, his circus catches bringing
the crowds to their feet time and
again. Up to last year he caught
for two years for the Baltimore
City College; and he will probably be called upon to catch this
spring.
Manager Coulter explained the
schedule and urged every man to
be present at the first practice to
be held on Saturday afternoon.
Slips were then passed around on
which the men were asked to sign
their names and state their previous baseball experience, where
they had played and what positions they had filled.
Among the old men, who are in
the" University this year, are
Dick Benson, Littman, Judefind,
who pitched last year, Love also a
pitcher, and Sickel, an outfielder.
These are the only men who remain from last year's team.
Among the new men out for the
team are: Elmer Jones, star halfback of last fall's football team,
who played in the outfield at City
College for several years and who
was captain of the team last
spring; Jack Moriarty, an outfielder, and Louis Moriarity, a
pitcher, both from Manchester
High School; Henry Lederer, a
catcher, and Dallam a pitcher,
from Dunhams; Nelson, Carey,

With the beginning of the new
term, the battalion, last week,
took up a new phase of the training, the subject of "Fire Direction
and Control." At the battalion
lecture, Major Guild pointed out
the fundamental importance, in
an engagement, of the proper control and direction of fire. Under
this head comes the designation
of sectors of fire, the determination of range, the designation of
objective, the rate of fire—in fact,
all those elements which enter
into the successful prosecution of
an engagement. One of the interesting exercises was the measuring of the extent of the objective by "fingers." That is, the arm
is held out at full length, and the
whole extent of the objective is
measured by the number of finger
breadths necessary to cover it. At
drill, therefore on the following
(lay, exercises in fire control
formed the main part of the drill.
Especially the rate of fire was
taken up. The men were instructed that firing at all ranges
is divided into three classes:
Ranges over 1,000 yards; ranges
between 500 and 1,000; and
ranges of 500 or under. In each
class the rate of fire may be slow,
normal, or fast. For each rate, at
each range, there is a definite
number of rounds per minute. The
practice at drill was in firing tin
correct number of rounds at the
various rates of fire, as determined by the captain's command
—for instance, range, 1,100 yards,
normal fire.
The results of the examination
in Military Science were very unsatisfactory; and it is known that
the commandant was greatly disappointed in the showing of the
battalion. There were several
high marks; but the average ot
the battalion was only 6.5. In
view of the fact that the members
of the battalion did so poorly, the
examination was made informal.
Hereafter, however, the men will
be held strictly responsible for all
work taken up at lectures or in the
quiz sections.
The class in Military Field Engineering received practical instruction in map sketching. After
twice pacing a 500-yard course in
'of
order to determine the length
his pace, each man constructed a
scale for his further use.

Lacrosse practice at the cage
has produced encouraging results.
The few veterans who are back
are showing flashes of the old-time
form, and several of the new men
are developing into real stars.
Line-ups and scrimmages are being held twice a week, and the
coaches are beginning to get a line
on the men in actual work in their
various positions. It also serves
the purpose of affording a comparison between the attack and the
defense, and helps in the building
up of a well-rounded team.
The close defense is showing up
particularly well. "Fritz" Sadtler, at goal, is learning rapidly,
and Jake Miller has shown that he
can step in and take care of things
in a creditable manner. Frank
Morely, John Stanley and Cashell
are fighting it out for point and
cover point. All three are football men, heavy and aggressive;
their stickwork is improving with
every practice. "Dutch" Schmidt
is playing first defense after the
fashion of the great Johnnie
Huck, who was about the best
man at that job anywhere to be
found. "Johnnie" was in a class
all his own, and for four years
was the mainstay of Hopkins' defense. Beall, Frisch, Golder, Kennedy and Defandorf, are the likeliest candidates for the mid-field
defense. The mid-field attack has
been weakened by the absence of
Captain Wolfe, who has been confine:1 to his bed with measles, but
Williams, Jarrett, Kauffman, and
Kennedy are showing up well, and
learning fast. The close attack has
been greatly strengthened by the
shifting of Baxley from the defense to first attack. Stuart, Baker, and Gardner are being used
at the home positions. Winslow,
star football man, who has been
out of the game with a badly swollen eye, is back in harness, and his
speed and fight are going to be a
great help to the attack.

Mr. Kistler's class in fencing is
progressing at an encouraging
rate, considering the lack of equipment. Major Guild watched the
manoeuvers for a while last Wednesday and expressed himself as
being much pleased with the facility with which the men have
caught on to the intricate movements of fencing.
The class now numbers about 10,
to whom lessons are assigned for
home study. The candidates must
not only know these lessons, but
must write out the substance of
them from memory and hand them
to the instructor. Foils and masks
have been ordered and are expected in a few (lays. Then the
real work of "assaults" or fencing
matches will begin in earnest. Already the men have been paired
off and several interesting matches
have taken place. All the candidates attest that it is most strenuous exercise but very interesting.
Five classes have been held to
date; they have been held every
Wednesday and Friday except
during examination week. These
Wednesday and Friday classes in
fencing will continue throughout
the year, including broadsword
and bayonet work after the foil
has been mastered. The men selected by Mr. Kistler will become
fencing instructors for the battalion, for a thorough course in
this art will be instituted in the
entire corps next year. Those men
showing up well so far are Davis,
Townsend, Dougherty, Evans, De
Marco, Bowen, Porter, Coleman,
Ma
n
ad
Bresee. Selected
men from this group will form a
nucleus, around which a fencing
team will probably be built for
next year.

"Trench and Camp," the, newspaper issued at Camp Meade, is
featuring the relay with Camp

anxious to get revenge for the
football defeat last fall, but the
New Jersey people are sending
down a team that lead eight service teams in the recent Milrose
meet, with J. Howard Berry, the
great Penn athlete as anchor man.
The colleges have entered teams
in greater numbers than even in
1917, partly due to the fact that
the Johns Hopkins has dared to
stage a meet—which is thp -only
one in the Middle South. The feature relay is between the University of Pennsylvania and its old
rival, Cornell the distance is two
miles. Penn has two other relay
teams, and it is rumored that
Georgia. Tech may , meet one of
them. The Penn squad consists of
20 men.
Georgia Tech is sending a team
North for the first time and the
coming of Strupper and Guyon,
the Indian, is in itself an event.
Everybody has read of the feats
of the two on the football field;
but Strupper alone took over 10
firsts in the short distances and
hurdles in 1916 and 1917 in the
South. He will have to fight his
way in the 220—open against such
men as Sherman Landers, University of Pennsylvania; Tommy McDonagh; the very fast George C.
Griffin, also of Georgia Tech; Dan
Bratt, of Hopkins; and Mitchell,
a Western Star, running under
the Baltimore Athletic Club.

Guyon, Landers, McDonagh, Erdman, Princeton's flyer, as well as
Gates of Georgetown. Cornell is
sending down Dresser, the intercollegiate cross-country champion;
but he will be forced to the limit
by Weeks, who has been in training to repeat his last year's victory and by Raymond, of Princeton.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—If there is one thing in
connection with the Johns Hopkins University that needs correction more than another, it is the
poor attendance at the chapel exercises conducted by the V. M. C.
A. Certainly, they are held at an
inconvenient time, the lunch hour
for most students, and no definite
inducement to attend is offered.
That is, points are not granted for
attendance, time that could be
spent in scholastic work is occupied, and, perhaps most important
of all, the exercises do not appear
to have any connection with the
University proper. It is very
likely that the seeming indifference of the University authorities
is responsible for the absence of
so many. But.whatever the cause,
this has been the state of affairs
for some time and seems likely to
remain so. The students appear to
regard the chapel with indifference; they say nothing derogatory
in regard to it, but still they do

Cornell—Thirty future mechanical engineers from the senior
class will begin government work
in the shipyards at Wilmington,
Del., on February 4. They will
continue their studies, having lectures four nights a week. Twentyeight seniors in electrical engineering will go to Schenectady to
work for the government. All will
return to Ithaca in May to receive
their diplomas.

Registrar Ball has recently received a letter from Dr. William
E. Gates, A. B.,'86, who is now in
Mexico, and who tells of his appointment as honorary professor
in the National Museum of Mexico. He says: "Under present conditions I am especially glad to receive this honor, as being the only
American, and the nomination being accounted as the highest that
can be conferred In Mexico. Special exploration privilege for a
term of years in some of the most
important ancient ruined cities
have also been granted me, and,
with the soon-to-be-expected complete pacification of the country,
I hope it will be possible to do important work."
The officio, which tells of his appointment, speaks of Dr. Gates as
being the first American to be signally honored and his "valuable
studies in archaeology, ethnology,
and anthropology" and "his most
complete and notable works on
the ruins of Yucatan."

TWO NEW COURSES ANNOUNCED
One Leading to B. S. in Chemistry
Other, Leading to Admission to New
School of Hygiene'—Will Attract New Students.

The Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University have
announced two important new
courses, which have been established on account of the new school of
Hygiene and Public Health and on
account of the demand for industrial chemistry. One course given
in the College of Arts and Sciences, leads to admission to the
new School of Hygiene. The other
course leads to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Chemistry.
Owing to conditions growing
out of the war and in response to
a demand from the agricultural
industries of the country, it was
felt that additional opportunities
should be offered to the young
men of the State to obtain training in advance chemical work
during the college course. The
new course is under the direction of the School of Engineering
and identical with the prescribed
engineering course for the first
two years. In the third year chemistry is substituted for two of the
engineering subjects, and in the
last year, practically all of the
student's..time is devoted to special work in the chemical laboratory. It is hoped that students in
this course will be better prepared
to carry on advanced work in all
lines of industrial chemistry than
students who have followed the
so-called courses in chemical-engineering, given by a number of
institutions throughout the country. Students who enter the new
course will be eligible to the State
scholarships awarded in, the Engineering School.
A student, who completes the
course, with two units of Latin
(which may be offered for matriculation) and with the equivalent
of Biology I (as certified by our
department of biology).will be accepted for admission to the Medical School.
An outline of the courses follows:
I.

IN MEMORY OF DR. MALL
(Remarks of President Goodnow,who
presided at the commemoration exercises for Dr. Mall on Sunday, February
3, at C. E. Hall.)

We are assembled here today to
honor the memory of our lamented colleague and friend Dr. Mall. Dr. Mall had been up to the
time of his death continuously and
uninterruptedly associated with
the Medical School from the time
of its opening. He was one of the
group who a quarter of a century
ago inaugurated a new venture in
medical instruction in this country. The purposes which were
then outlined, the ideas which
were then entertained, the methods which were then adopted had
subsequently a widespread influence throughout the land. It is
somewhat -difficult for us, separated as we are by so long a period from the original time of
their formulation and accustomed
as we are to the changes which
they caused, to appreciate how
novel and how important was the
work then undertaken.
For the success attendant upon
the Medical School Dr. Mall was
in no small measure responsible.
A brilliant and tireless investigator he made invaluable contributions to the science to which he
devoted himself and won prestige
for the institution with which he
was connected. A wise and sane
counselor he exercised a potent
and salutary influence over the
policy of the medical faculty. A
kindly and courteous gentleman
he greatly endeared himself to his
colleagues and associates.
Passing away in the prime of
life and at the height of his powers he leaves in the world of science a gap which it will be difficult to fill and among his friends
a sense of loss which it is impossible to overcome.
We have, however the satisfaction of knowing that
' the University of which he was a member
is better and finer for what he was
and did. His life and work will
long continue to be an inspiration to the colleagues he has left
behind and to the students whom
he taught.

Alex. Barton Writes From France.
[Alexander K. Barton, from whom
the following letter comes, was a prominent member of the Class of 1914. He
was elected Rhode Scholar in the year
he graduated, but had to forego the
privileges of the honor on account of
the war. He was also editor of THE
NEWS-LETTER during the year 19131914. THE NEWS-LEAThR is indebted
to Dean Brush for the privilege of
publishing this intensely interesting
account]

January 25, 1918.
149th F. A., A. E. F., France
DEAR MR. BRUSH—
I have been intending to write
for some time, but have been putting it off. Would that I had not
been so delinquent and had pursued Fraser and Squair more ardently! A lot of charming French
ladies hold a Red Cross (French)
Bazar at camp and how I curse
my inability to "parler" with fluency. We entertain them at our
officers mess, and after having
skillfully maneuvered so that
Mlle. la plus belle et plus charmante sits at my table, a sous-lieutenant comes along and does
nearly all the talking. Tell any of
your students to put the classics
aside, not to say the sciences, and
to learn French. I have met some
charming people. They are most
hospitable. Had a good game of
tennis the Sunday before Christmas with some French girls at a
town in Brittany. It was funny
to sap "pret?" and "guaranteeing." Being with Americans so
much and having no chance to
study, it is hard to make much
progress, but what French I did
know has come back in a remarkable way, and I have picked up a
lot. It has been a tremendous
pleasure to be able to talk to
French officers and to the country
people. When I cannot understand the spoken word I get them
to write it down. I had quite
an extensive conversation with a
French lieutenant en route from
Paris to this place (the First
Corps School). I have written
quite a few French letters. My
knowledge of French has been a
great help in a military way—so
many directions in regard to the
soixante-quinze and to signalling
apparatus are not yet translated.
I have seen quite a few interesting places—one old town near the
last camp. The castle walls are
still intact, a deep moat in front
of them and in the town a church
with beautiful stone carvings and
stained glass windows, built by
the English when they held that

part of France. I had two great
days in Paris. I translated what
our French guide had to say in
the Palais de Justice to a party
of officers. It is remarkable how
practice helps your French. I
saw Leslie Buckler in Paris. He
took me to supper at a club for allied officers, which occupies the
handsome house of Baron Rothschild.
I should think THE NEWS-LETTER or ALUMNI MAGAZINE Would
be interested in hearing of the
Johns Hopkins University men in
our first four thousand. There are
quite a few in the First Division.
Lieut.-Col. John Crane (who came
to see me one night, but whom I
missed). Maj. Redmond Stewart,
Acting Judge Advocate of the First
Division,Whom I see frequently, as
he is located here. Gillie, whom I
just ran into tonight here at the Y.
M. C. A., and Jim Manning. Hunting, a Phi Gama about '07, is here.
Jack Branham is at the Infantry
School here,I just learned tonight,
and shall look him up tomorrow.
Besides the Hopkins Unit (which
is nearby), there will be many of
us in the First Corps.
I am mighty anxious to get "aux
tranchees," and I guess I'll be as
ready to get out. The artillery
takes a long time to train unfortunately. We get splendid food—
can get excellently cooked meals
at the inns for four or five francs
if we want a change, but the army
food is really excellent. Our quarters are good, with plenty of wood,
but the last two weeks have been
so mild we often go without coats.
The Y. M. C. A. is closing and I
must stop. Hoping the Maryland
F. A. battalion will soon get over,
Fraternally,
ALEXANDER K. BARTON.
News From Capt. Elliott

A Training Camp, Somewhere in
France.
January 28, 1917.

MY DEAR DR. BRUSH:
Just a line to let you and my
many friends at Hopkins know
that I arrived safely across the
"big ditch" after an uneventful
voyage. We are hard at work here
under French instructors trying
to master the gentle art of
"beating the Dutch." The Army
seems to be in high spirits and
hopeful of an early whack at
Fritz so that we can all be home
for Christmas. Weather here like
spring at home, warm and sunny.
Our only woe is the hick of mail
and news. With kindest regards
to all at the club.
Please remember me to Konze,
Bitter, and "George," the Janitor.
C. W. ELLIOTT.
Warden—In this institution,
we aim to put every man to work
at his regular occupation.
Now what is your business?
No. 3333—Traveling salesman.
—Chaparal.

Objects of Loan in this Form
The objects of the United States
Government in selling these WarSavings Certificate Stamps($5.00)
and Thrift Stamps (25 cents) are
fourfold:
1. To obtain $2,000,000,000 for
use in the prosecution of the
World War in which we are now
engaged;
2. To encourage habits of
economy and conservation upon
the part of our people, thereby
adding to the available wealth and
resources of our country, and
saving both for the use of our
military forces and those at home
who are in need;
3. To encourage the habits of
thrift and saving in America, and
4. To give every citizen of
America an opportunity to do his
or her part toward winning this
War for Universal Liberty.

BENSON TO LEAD BALL TEAM

LEARNS MORE ABOUT SHOOTING

LACROSSE SQUAD LOOKS GOOD

CLASS IN FENCING PROGRESSING

Star Outfielder of Last Year's Base
Ball Team Elected Captain at
Organization Meeting
For This Year.

Battalion Takes Up Work in Fire
Direction and Control— Results
of Examinations are
Unsatisfactory.

Men Are Getting Down to Real Work.
Schmidt,Sadtler,Morley and Winslow
Setting Fast Pace—New Men
Learn Quickly.

Sergt. Kistler's Proteges Are Rapidly
Learning the Art----Plan to Organize
a Fencing Team for Next Year.

If the enthusiasm of the large
crowd that attended the baseball
organization meeting held• on
Tuesday, February 12, in the Civil
Engineering Building, can be
taken as a criterion, the baseball
team this year, despite the loss of
so many men on account of the
war, will be one of the best that
has ever represented the Johns
Hopkins University. The chief
business of the meeting was the
election of a captain to lead the
1918 team, and "Dick" Benson,
last year's star outfielder, was selected for this honored position.
The baseball team lost the services of its captain for this year,
Stuart Egerton, when he enlisted
in the battery last spring. He is
now at Camp McClellan, Anniston, Alabama, with a whole colony of Hopkins men.
Coach Eddie Hooper was unable to get here to address the
men and Manager Coulter, who
was in charge of the meeting,
started things moving with the
election of a captain. There were
only two logical men for this position, Dick Benson and Lawrence
Littman, last year's third basemen, and Dick was elected. Benson, while only a sophomore, has
had considerable baseball experience, and is unquestionably qualified to perform the duties of captain. He played in the outfield in
all of the games last year and was
the individual star in many of
them, his circus catches bringing
the crowds to their feet time and
again. Up to last year he caught
for two years for the Baltimore
City College; and he will probably be called upon to catch this
spring.
Manager Coulter explained the
schedule and urged every man to
be present at the first practice to
be held on Saturday afternoon.
Slips were then passed around on
which the men were asked to sign
their names and state their previous baseball experience, where
they had played and what positions they had filled.
Among the old men, who are in
the" University this year, are
Dick Benson, Littman, Judefind,
who pitched last year, Love also a
pitcher, and Sickel, an outfielder.
These are the only men who remain from last year's team.
Among the new men out for the
team are: Elmer Jones, star halfback of last fall's football team,
who played in the outfield at City
College for several years and who
was captain of the team last
spring; Jack Moriarty, an outfielder, and Louis Moriarity, a
pitcher, both from Manchester
High School; Henry Lederer, a
catcher, and Dallam a pitcher,
from Dunhams; Nelson, Carey,

With the beginning of the new
term, the battalion, last week,
took up a new phase of the training, the subject of "Fire Direction
and Control." At the battalion
lecture, Major Guild pointed out
the fundamental importance, in
an engagement, of the proper control and direction of fire. Under
this head comes the designation
of sectors of fire, the determination of range, the designation of
objective, the rate of fire—in fact,
all those elements which enter
into the successful prosecution of
an engagement. One of the interesting exercises was the measuring of the extent of the objective by "fingers." That is, the arm
is held out at full length, and the
whole extent of the objective is
measured by the number of finger
breadths necessary to cover it. At
drill, therefore on the following
(lay, exercises in fire control
formed the main part of the drill.
Especially the rate of fire was
taken up. The men were instructed that firing at all ranges
is divided into three classes:
Ranges over 1,000 yards; ranges
between 500 and 1,000; and
ranges of 500 or under. In each
class the rate of fire may be slow,
normal, or fast. For each rate, at
each range, there is a definite
number of rounds per minute. The
practice at drill was in firing tin
correct number of rounds at the
various rates of fire, as determined by the captain's command
—for instance, range, 1,100 yards,
normal fire.
The results of the examination
in Military Science were very unsatisfactory; and it is known that
the commandant was greatly disappointed in the showing of the
battalion. There were several
high marks; but the average ot
the battalion was only 6.5. In
view of the fact that the members
of the battalion did so poorly, the
examination was made informal.
Hereafter, however, the men will
be held strictly responsible for all
work taken up at lectures or in the
quiz sections.
The class in Military Field Engineering received practical instruction in map sketching. After
twice pacing a 500-yard course in
'of
order to determine the length
his pace, each man constructed a
scale for his further use.

Lacrosse practice at the cage
has produced encouraging results.
The few veterans who are back
are showing flashes of the old-time
form, and several of the new men
are developing into real stars.
Line-ups and scrimmages are being held twice a week, and the
coaches are beginning to get a line
on the men in actual work in their
various positions. It also serves
the purpose of affording a comparison between the attack and the
defense, and helps in the building
up of a well-rounded team.
The close defense is showing up
particularly well. "Fritz" Sadtler, at goal, is learning rapidly,
and Jake Miller has shown that he
can step in and take care of things
in a creditable manner. Frank
Morely, John Stanley and Cashell
are fighting it out for point and
cover point. All three are football men, heavy and aggressive;
their stickwork is improving with
every practice. "Dutch" Schmidt
is playing first defense after the
fashion of the great Johnnie
Huck, who was about the best
man at that job anywhere to be
found. "Johnnie" was in a class
all his own, and for four years
was the mainstay of Hopkins' defense. Beall, Frisch, Golder, Kennedy and Defandorf, are the likeliest candidates for the mid-field
defense. The mid-field attack has
been weakened by the absence of
Captain Wolfe, who has been confine:1 to his bed with measles, but
Williams, Jarrett, Kauffman, and
Kennedy are showing up well, and
learning fast. The close attack has
been greatly strengthened by the
shifting of Baxley from the defense to first attack. Stuart, Baker, and Gardner are being used
at the home positions. Winslow,
star football man, who has been
out of the game with a badly swollen eye, is back in harness, and his
speed and fight are going to be a
great help to the attack.

Mr. Kistler's class in fencing is
progressing at an encouraging
rate, considering the lack of equipment. Major Guild watched the
manoeuvers for a while last Wednesday and expressed himself as
being much pleased with the facility with which the men have
caught on to the intricate movements of fencing.
The class now numbers about 10,
to whom lessons are assigned for
home study. The candidates must
not only know these lessons, but
must write out the substance of
them from memory and hand them
to the instructor. Foils and masks
have been ordered and are expected in a few (lays. Then the
real work of "assaults" or fencing
matches will begin in earnest. Already the men have been paired
off and several interesting matches
have taken place. All the candidates attest that it is most strenuous exercise but very interesting.
Five classes have been held to
date; they have been held every
Wednesday and Friday except
during examination week. These
Wednesday and Friday classes in
fencing will continue throughout
the year, including broadsword
and bayonet work after the foil
has been mastered. The men selected by Mr. Kistler will become
fencing instructors for the battalion, for a thorough course in
this art will be instituted in the
entire corps next year. Those men
showing up well so far are Davis,
Townsend, Dougherty, Evans, De
Marco, Bowen, Porter, Coleman,
Ma
n
ad
Bresee. Selected
men from this group will form a
nucleus, around which a fencing
team will probably be built for
next year.

New Jersey people are sending

coming of Strupper and Guyon,

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—If there is one thing in
connection with the Johns Hopkins University that needs correction more than another, it is the
poor attendance at the chapel exercises conducted by the V. M. C.
A. Certainly, they are held at an
inconvenient time, the lunch hour
for most students, and no definite
inducement to attend is offered.
That is, points are not granted for
attendance, time that could be
spent in scholastic work is occupied, and, perhaps most important
of all, the exercises do not appear
to have any connection with the
University proper. It is very
likely that the seeming indifference of the University authorities
is responsible for the absence of
so many. But.whatever the cause,
this has been the state of affairs
for some time and seems likely to
remain so. The students appear to
regard the chapel with indifference; they say nothing derogatory
in regard to it, but still they do

Cornell—Thirty future mechanical engineers from the senior
class will begin government work
in the shipyards at Wilmington,
Del., on February 4. They will
continue their studies, having lectures four nights a week. Twentyeight seniors in electrical engineering will go to Schenectady to
work for the government. All will
return to Ithaca in May to receive
their diplomas.

"May I see Barker, please?" she
asked at the hospital. She was
very pretty.
"We don't allow anyone but relatives to see the patients. Are you
a member of his family?" asked
the matron.
"Why, yes," she answered blushingly. Then boldly: "I'm his sister."
"Oh, really," answered the matron, "I'm so glad to meet you.
I'm his mother."—Lehigh Burr.

Registrar Ball has recently received a letter from Dr. William
E. Gates, A. B.,'86, who is now in
Mexico, and who tells of his appointment as honorary professor
in the National Museum of Mexico. He says: "Under present conditions I am especially glad to receive this honor, as being the only
American, and the nomination being accounted as the highest that
can be conferred In Mexico. Special exploration privilege for a
term of years in some of the most
important ancient ruined cities
have also been granted me, and,
with the soon-to-be-expected complete pacification of the country,
I hope it will be possible to do important work."
The officio, which tells of his appointment, speaks of Dr. Gates as
being the first American to be signally honored and his "valuable
studies in archaeology, ethnology,
and anthropology" and "his most
complete and notable works on
the ruins of Yucatan."
